facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 116 to 125 of 1961 were filed by special leave from the judgment and decrees dated March 4, 1955, of the former Andhra Pradesh High Court, Guntur, in S.T. Appeals Nos. 83,85-88,90,91 and 119-121 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by. special leave from the judgment and decrees dated March 4, 1955, of the former Andhra Pradesh High Court, Guntur, in S. T. Appeals Nos. 83,85-88,90,91 and 119- 121 of 1954.

facts.text: The appeals arise out of the order of the Tribunal appointed under s. 8 of the Madras Estates Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari Act, 1948 (Madras Act XXVI of 1948), apportioning the advance compensation and interim payments for Venkatagiri Estate.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals arise out of the order of the Tribunal appointed under s. 8 of the Madras Estates  Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari  Act, 1948  Madras Act XXVI of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act, apportioning the advance companypensation given and interim payments made in companynection with the vesting of the Venkatagiri Estate in the Government of Madras as a result of a numberification issued under sub-s.  4  of s. 1 of, the Act from the numberified date, i.e., September 7, 1949.

facts.text: Venkatagiri Estate vested in the Government of Madras on the notified date, September 7, 1949, by reason of s. 3(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: With effect from the numberified date, i.e., September 7, 1949, the entire Venkatagiri Estate stood transferred to the Government and vested in it by reason of s. 3 b  of the Act.

facts.text: The Act received assent of the Governor General on April 2, 1949, and sections including ss. 4 and 8 came into force at once.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the assent of the Governor General on April 2, 1949 and some of its sections, including ss. 4 and 8, mentioned in sub-s.  4  of s. 1, came into force at once.

facts.text: Government deposited Rs. 12,11,419/- as advance payment of compensation after deducting Rs. 7,28,500/- peishkush from half of estimated Rs. 19,39,919-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the Venkatagiri Estate, the Government deposited Rs. 12,11,419/- as and by way of advance payment of companypensation, after deducting Rs. 7,28,500/- payable to the Government by the Estate for peishkush out of the sum of Rs. 19,39,919-8-0, half of the estimated amount of companypensation payable.

facts.text: Government deposited Rs. 1,55,194/- as interim payment for each of Fasli years 1359 to 1362.

anchor.surface_text: The Government also deposited as interim payment Rs. 1,55,194/- for each of the Fasli years 1359 to 1362 F.

facts.text: Venkatagiri Estate is an ancient estate in North Arcot.

anchor.surface_text: The Venkatagiri Estate is an ancient estate in North Arcot and the necessary history of the estate for the purposes of this case is companytained in the document Exhibit A-1 with which we number deal.

facts.text: In 1878, Kumara Yachendra Bahadur Varu made over the estate to his eldest son Rajagopala Krishna Yachendra.

anchor.surface_text: Kumara Yachendra Bahadur Varu, who tops the genealogical table numbered above and his four sons mentioned therein, are parties to this document. ... The document recites that the estate had been made over in 1878 to Rajagopala Krishna Yachendra, the eldest of the four brothers, by their father Kumara Yachendra Bahadur Varu

facts.text: In 1889, two brothers Venkata Krishna Yachendra and Muddukrishna Yachendra desired partition of the estate, but father declared it impartible.

anchor.surface_text: In 1889, two of the brothers, Venkata Krishna Yachendra and Muddukrishna Yachendra, expressed a desire for the partition of the estate. The then Rajah, i.e., Rajagopala Krishna Yachendra, the eldest brother, asserted that it was number liable for partition.

facts.text: Exhibit A-1 is a family settlement document where father settled allowances of Rs. 1,000 per month to each of the four sons.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the final settlement between the father and his four sons are then numbered. They may be briefly mentioned. ... Each of the brothers was to get Rs. 1,000/- per mouth for the rest of his life.

facts.text: Madras Impartible Estates Act, 1904 came into force in 1904 and Venkatagiri Estate was included in its Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: In 1904, the Madras Impartible Estates Act, 1904  Act 11 of 1904  came into force. The Venkatagiri Estate was included in the Schedule of that Act and had to be deemed to be an impartible estate in view of s. 3 of that Act.

facts.text: Rajah Velugoti Kumara Krishna Yachendra (Krishna Bahadur), appellant in Appeal No. 117/1961, filed Original Petition No. 2300 of 1953 before the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Rajah Velugoti Kumara Krishna Yachendra, appellant in Appeal No. 117 of 1961, hereinafter called Krishna Bahadur, filed Original Petition No. 2300 of 1953 before the Tribunal.

facts.text: Three sons of Krishna Bahadur filed separate petitions: Ramakrishna Yachendra (CA 118), Rajagopala Krishna Yachendra (CA 119), Movva Gopala Krishna Yachendra (CA 116).

anchor.surface_text: Three of his sons Ramakrishna Yachendra, Rajagopala Krishna Yachendra and Movva Gopala Krishna Yachendra, appellants in Civil Appeals-Nos. 118, 119 and 116 of 1961, respectively, filed separate petitions.

facts.text: Appellants in CAs 116-119 contended they were entitled to compensation as sharers since estate lost impartible character on notified date.

anchor.surface_text: By their applications they raised the companytentions that they were entitled to an amount in the companypensation as sharers, as the impartible estate lost its character as such from the numberified date

facts.text: Tribunal fixed Rs. 75,000/- payable to Krishna Bahadur's branch out of Rs. 12,11,419/- advance compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal fixed Rs. 75,000/- as the amount payable to Krishna Bahadurs branch out of the sum of Rs. 12,11,419/- deposited as advance payment of companypensation

facts.text: Tribunal and Special Tribunal rejected contentions that s.45 of the Act was ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: None of these companytentions was accepted by the Tribunal or by the Special Tribunal companystituted in accordance with s. 21 of the Act for bearing appeals against the orders of the Tribunal.

facts.text: Present Rajah filed Civil Appeals Nos. 120-125 of 1961 challenging the basis of maintenance calculation.

anchor.surface_text: The Rajah has therefore filed Civil Appeals Nos. 120 to 123 of 1961. He has also filed two appeals Nos. 124 and 125 with respect to the interim payments

facts.text: Supreme Court held that s.45 of the Act is not ultra vires and does not violate Art.14 due to Art.31B and Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Theattack on the validity of s. 45 of the Act on the ground of its companytravening the provisions of Art 14 of the Constitution is number open to the appellants in view of Art. 31B ... The Act is mentioned at item No. 10 in the Ninth Schedule.

facts.text: Appellants in 116-119 are not sharers under s.45(2) as they do not come under principal landholder and his male line descendants on notified date.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants do number companye under any of the persons mentioned in this clause and therefore they cannot get, companypensation as sharers.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have stated above, we dismiss all the appeals with companyts, one hearing fee for Civil Appeals Nos. 116 to 119 and one hearing fee for C I Appeals Nos.

appointed under s. 8 of the Madras Estates Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari Act, 1948 (Madras Act XXVI of 1948), hereinafter called the Act, apportioning the advance compensation given and interim payments made in connection with the vesting of the Venkatagiri Estate in the Government of Madras as a result of a notification issued under sub-s. 4 of s. 1 of, the Act from the notified date, i.e., September 7, 1949.

concepts.unlisted_description: Tribunal appointment under Madras Estates Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: notification issued under sub-s. 4 of s. 1 of, the Act from the notified date, i.e., September 7, 1949.
The Act received the assent of the Governor General on April 2, 1949 and some of its sections, including ss. 4 and 8, mentioned in sub-s. 4 of s. 1, came into force at once.
With effect from the notified date, i.e., September 7, 1949, the entire Venkatagiri Estate stood transferred to the Government and vested in it by reason of s. 3 b of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 39 provides for the Director of Settlements to determine the basic annual sum in respect of the estate and also the total compensation payable in respect of the estate, in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

Section 54-A provides that the Government shall estimate roughly the amount of compensation payable in respect of the estate and deposit one-half of that amount within six months from the notified date in the office of the Tribunal as advance payment on account of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In 1904, the Madras Impartible Estates Act, 1904 (Act II of 1904) came into force. The Venkatagiri Estate was included in the Schedule of that Act and had to be deemed to be an impartible estate in view of s. 3 of that Act.

Section 9 of that Act mentioned the persons entitled to maintenance out of the impartible estate, where for the purpose of ascertaining the succession to the impartible estate the estate had to be regarded as the property of a joint Hindu family.
other persons who, immediately before the notified date,were entitled to maintenance out of the estate and its income either under section 9 or 12 of the Madras Impartible Estates Act, 1904

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 provides for the filing of claims to the compensation before the Tribunal by persons claiming any amount by way of a share or by way of maintenance or otherwise and by creditors.

By s. 43, the tribunal is to inquire into the validity of the claims and determine the persons who, in its opinion, are entitled to the compensation deposited and the amount to which each of them is entitled.

Section 44 provides that as a preliminary to the final determination, the Tribunal shall apportion the compensation among such persons whose rights or interests in the estates stood transferred to the Government, including persons who are entitled to be maintained from the estate and its Income
Special Tribunal constituted in accordance with s. 21 of the Act for hearing appeals against the orders of the Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether Section 45 and other provisions of the Act are ultra vires the State Legislature for want of legislative competence as the Legislature had no power to enact a law disturbing the rights of a joint family?

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of s. 45 of the Act were ultra vires the State Legislature and were discriminatory and so void

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s. 45 are discriminatory and offend Art. 14 of the Constitution as they provide for the maintenance-holders to get 1/5th out of the compensation while the proprietor and his sons are to get 4/5ths out of it after satisfying the claims of the creditors?

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of s. 45 are discriminatory and offend Art. 14 of the Constitution as they provide for the maintenanceholders to get 1/5th out of the compensation while the proprietor and his sons are to get 4/5ths out of it after satisfying the claims of the creditors

issues.text: Whether the allowance payable under the family settlement document Exhibit A-1 constitutes a debt making the claimants creditors rather than maintenance-holders?

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the allowance is a debt owed by the Rajah-landholder to his brothers to whom the allowance was to be paid. It might have been so only if it was postulated that the Rajah had purchased the share of the other members of the family and was paying the sale price in the form of an allowance. This is, not what the document Exhibit A-1 recites.

issues.text: Whether the amount of peishkush payable by the Venkatagiri Estate to the Government was not to be deducted from the compensation when calculating maintenance amount payable to the maintenance-holders?

anchor.surface_text: The amount of peishkush payable by the Venkatagiri Estate to the Government was not to be deducted from the compensation when calculating maintenance amount payable to the maintenance. holders.

issues.text: Whether the impartible character of the Venkatagiri Estate ceased when the Estate vested in the Government on September 7, 1949, with the result that the compensation does not bear the character of impartibility and became the property of the joint family?

Whether the appellants should have got share in the compensation as sharers on account of the partible character of the estate reviving on the notified date as a result of the repeal of the Impartible Estates Act, 1904?

Whether the amount of maintenance payable out of compensation should bear the same proportion to the total compensation as the monthly allowance under Exhibit A-1 bears to the income of the Estate in 1889 (about 1/50th)?

holdings.text: The amount of peishkush was properly deducted from the estimated compensation before apportionment to maintenance-holders under s.54A.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of peishkush payable by the Venkatagiri Estate to the Government was not to be deducted from the compensation when calculating maintenance amount payable to the maintenance. holders. Now, the amount of peishkush payable to the Government had to be deducted out of the amount to be deposited under sub- s.  1  of s. 54-A in view of the provisions of its sub-s.  2

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.54A(2) expressly allows deduction of peishkush from deposit; apportionment is of net amount after liabilities; real compensation is value minus liabilities.

holdings.text: The allowance under Exhibit A-1 is maintenance, not a debt owed by the Rajah.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the allowance is a debt owed by the Rajah-landholder to his brothers to whom the allowance was to be paid. It might have been so only if it was postulated that the Rajah had purchased the share

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document does not indicate purchase of shares; allowance indefinite and for maintenance despite terminology; prior reference as maintenance; courts below correct.

holdings.text: Section 45 of the Act is not ultra vires the State Legislature for lack of competence.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was made by the State Legislature by virtue of Entry 21 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, which reads Land, that is to say, rights in or over land... The Act was enacted by the State Legislature by virtue of item No. 9, List II, Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act which reads Compulsory acquisition of land. The Act is not ultra vires the State Legislature

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act under Entry 9 List II GOI Act 1935 (compulsory acquisition); acquires estate vesting in government, not succession/distribution.

holdings.text: Section 45 of the Act does not contravene Article 14 due to protection under Article 31B and Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Theattack on the validity of s. 45 of the Act on the ground of its companytravening the provisions of Art 14 of the Constitution is number open to the appellants in view of Art. 31B ... The Act is mentioned at item No. 10 in the Ninth Schedule. We therefore hold that the provisions of s. 45 of the Act are number void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.31B immunizes Ninth Schedule Acts (item 10: MEAA) from Part III challenges including Art.14.

holdings.text: Appellants in CAs 116-119 are not sharers entitled to compensation under s.45(2)(a).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sharers limited to principal landholder and male line descendants (sons, grandsons, great-grandsons) on notified date; appellants outside this; estate impartible until vesting; rights post-vesting per Act only.

holdings.text: Impartible estate's character determines apportionment up to notified date; compensation distributed per s.45 despite vesting.

anchor.surface_text: The estate was impartible up to the moment it vested in the Government on the numberified date. Whatever be the nature of the companypensation payable, the distribution of the companypensation between the persons who had an interest in the estate would be in accordance with the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 45

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 vests estate, extinguishes prior rights; new rights per Act; s.45 applies to impartible estates regarded as joint family for succession pre-notified date.

holdings.text: Tribunal correctly apportioned maintenance without fixed historical proportion from 1889 income; per s.45(5) factors.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.45(5) directs regard to compensation amount, number of persons, relationship, other income, circumstances; no authorization for historical income proportion; prior arrangement considered factors, not fixed ratio; Tribunal followed Act.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have stated above, we dismiss all the appeals with costs, one hearing fee for Civil Appeals Nos. 116 to 119 and one hearing fee for C I Appeals Nos.

directions: one hearing fee for Civil Appeals Nos. 116 to 119
one hearing fee for Civil Appeals Nos. 120 to 125
